awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Uncovering the Role of Sirtuins in Linking Food Availability and Stress Tolerance Through Multi-Scale Signaling Networks in Mussels
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the major aims of biology is to explain how changes that occur at the sub-cellular level affect the function at higher levels of biological organization, such as organs or the whole organism. Specifically, how are changes in the expression of genes and proteins, and the concentration of metabolites of a cell, affecting the organ of which the cell is a part?  Furthermore, when do these changes in organ function affect properties of the whole organism?  Using the California mussel Mytilus californianus, we ask, when do subcellular changes in gill cells affect feeding rate or changes in muscle biochemistry affect the ability to close their shells? We aim to address these questions by collecting data from different levels of biological organization simultaneously, from the subcellular to the organ and organism levels in response to relevant environmental stressors, such as food availability, heat stress and the inhibition of signaling pathways. The investigators' expertise in comparative environmental physiology and computational mathematics will enable them to address the relevance of subcellular changes to predict organ and organism level changes using a mathematical model. The proposal has a strong training component and is centered on lowering the barriers to molecular and computational technologies and building a diverse community of young scientists in integrative organismal biology. Furthermore, K-12 resources will be developed on the physiological impacts of future environmental change that align with Common Core and Next Generation Science Standards.

The specific objective of this study is to develop quantitative, predictive models that uncover the underlying interactions/regulations among subcellular networks (transcriptomic, metabolomic and proteomic or TMP) and their effect at the phenotypes of the organ and organism in response to environmentally relevant stressors (i.e., low/high food availability and low/high body temperature), based on high-throughput experimental data, in the intertidal mussel Mytilus californianus. The experimental design will also focus on testing a possible mechanistic link between food availability and stress tolerance by inhibiting signaling pathways involving sirtuins, which are deacylases that respond to caloric restriction and stress. This proposal distinguishes itself from previous studies on the thermal physiology of intertidal organisms in that it incorporates statistical models (including regression and decision trees) to uncover the regulatory structure of the TMP networks and determine whether the resulting topology accurately predicts observed phenotypic responses measured at the organ and whole organism levels. The PIs' complementary expertise in TMP analyses, integrative biology and computational modeling will enable them to combine "omics" technologies, organismal physiology and computational approaches to advance integrative organismal biology. The PIs are planning to disseminate the modeling framework through a research coordination network (RCN) on Integrative Organismal Biology. The results will improve our ability to predict how mussels will respond to future environmental change and thereby improve our understanding of the role of mussel aquaculture in providing a secure and sustainable food resource in the future.

por.por_cntn:
Climate change is predicted to increase the annual mean global temperature, but it is also forecasted to increase temperature variability and stochasticity. Currently, the majority of our understanding of thermal physiology of intertidal organisms has come from laboratory experiments that acclimate organisms to submerged conditions and steady-state increases in temperatures. For organisms that experience the ebb and flow of tides with unpredictable low tide conditions, the unrealistic combination of these conditions presents concern for the reliability of reported tolerances and thus predicted responses to climate change. The current project examined the integrative response (from changes in the transcriptome to whole organism measures of performance) of the California mussel (Mytilus californianus) to projected changes in thermal regimes in the rocky intertidal to better understand aspects of environmental complexity (e.g. repeated emersion, unpredictable temperature regimes) that are important modulators of stress tolerance. In addition, this projected also focused on how food availability and changes in energy status affected the capacity of mussels to cope with warming, with a specific focus on the role of sirtuins in linking caloric intake and stress tolerance. One of the greatest impacts of the project has been a demonstration that environmental complexity matters in terms of understanding mechanisms of stress tolerance in intertidal organisms. Research in both limpets and mussels demonstrated that it is in fact the daily aerial exposure during low tide (the predictable environmental cue in intertidal habitats) that is the predominant factor determining stress tolerance in intertidal mollusks and not thermal history, which has been a predominant area of study. Adding an increase in temperature during low tide doesn?t significantly increase thermal tolerance, unless it is applied in an unpredictable manner. We demonstrate that an unpredictable thermal regime during low tide best approximates the cardiac performance, temperature sensitivity and thermal tolerance of field acclimatized mussels. The results of this project demonstrate that in order to provide an accurate prediction of the tolerance of intertidal organisms to changing temperatures, experiments must incorporate realistic environmental conditions including aerial exposure and stochastic environmental temperatures. Although the mechanisms underlying this are still a work in progress, it appears that the stochastic environmental signal is important for modulating energy metabolism in a distinct way from animals exposed to predictable changes in environmental temperature. The project trained 6 graduate students, two undergraduate students, and two laboratory technicians at UC Davis as well as dozens of undergraduates and two postdoctoral scholars at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo. The project will provide genomic, transcriptomic and proteomic resources to the scientific community. In addition to conducting research, this project engaged collaborators from the UK, Australia and Hong Kong as well as shellfish farmers in the US and the UK to begin to discuss and implement stress management and selective breeding strategies for future-proofing shellfish aquaculture in a changing climate. Lastly, this project engaged the K-12 students and the public through different venues on issues related to global climate change and threats to coastal communities.
